title: Porridge writers reveal that they intended the sitcom to show the tough reality of prison
text:
It's been hailed as one of the best British sitcoms of all time - a lighthearted look at the camaraderie and banter between inmates and prison officers.

But the writers of Porridge told how they nevertheless wanted audiences to know that ‘prison is not fun’.

Dick Clement and Ian La Frenais also revealed Ronnie Barker, who starred as scheming inmate Norman Stanley Fletcher, came up with his own jokes which were written into the script.

Dick Clement and Ian La Frenais, who have spent recent decades mostly working in Hollywood, also revealed their first big hit, The Likely Lads, was viewed as an unlikely hit when first commissioned in the early days of BBC2

Giving a talk at the Cheltenham Literary Festival, Clement said: ‘We always wanted our shows to be grounded in reality - even with prison, which was the toughest.

‘We knew we had to make people laugh but we wanted to let people know that prison is not fun, it certainly isn’t.’

It led to the decision to include an episode in the first series which is largely set in the cell Fletcher shared with Richard Beckinsale’s character, Lennie Godber.

During the episode, called ‘A Night In’, both men ponder various aspects of their lives.

It's been hailed as one of the best British sitcoms of all time - a lighthearted look at the camaraderie and banter between inmates and prison officers. But the writers of Porridge told how they nevertheless wanted audiences to know that ‘prison is not fun’

Fletcher voices his unhappiness at having to share a cell because he thought he would be on his own - and attempts to impose strict rules on his younger cellmate.

Clement said: ‘We felt prison’s about being locked up and we should have at least (once) where the whole episode takes place within a cell.

‘Godber’s admitting that he’s scared and he doesn’t know how he’s going to get through.’

Describing how the famous one-liner from the 1970s series came about, La Frenais said: ‘Ronnie would come up with a gag.

‘He was a lovely man, Ronnie. He’d say, I thought of this and would run it by you, in respect of the writer, and we said, well, of course. Of course it’s fine.

‘But it’s true that most of our comedy comes out of character. It’s organic... We don’t go round in circles because we’ve thought of a funny gag. It’s never been our thing.’

Clement added: ‘We’ve never seen ourselves as gag writers. Occasionally a gag comes along and we’d pick it up and use it but we don’t really go out of our way to create gags as such.

‘There’s always comedy in life anyway.’

They recalled how Frank Muir, then assistant head of light entertainment at the corporation, told them [that the Likely Lads , pictured above] ‘it wouldn’t do anything but it’s cheap’. Rodney Brewes is pictured left as Bob Ferris, and James Bolam is seen as Terry Collier

Citing some of their other creations - such as Auf Wiedersehen, Pet, which follows a group of out-of-work British tradesmen forced to look for work in West Germany - Clement said: ‘We wanted Auf Wiedersehen, Pet to feel real and we never saw that as a comedy series by the way, we just wanted to let the comedy, if there was any, to come out of it.’

The pair, who have spent recent decades mostly working in Hollywood, also revealed their first big hit, The Likely Lads, was viewed as an unlikely hit when first commissioned in the early days of BBC2.

It was chosen because the corporation did not have to pay them much for the script, as they were not well-known at the time.

They recalled how Frank Muir, then assistant head of light entertainment at the corporation, told them ‘it wouldn’t do anything but it’s cheap’.

Clement, 82, and La Frenais, 83, say they are still working in the film industry in America but are having difficulties because it is prioritising productions based on ‘video games, graphic novels and Marvel comics’.

Clement said: ‘It’s not us. We try to write grown-up movies so there’s less opportunities although we’ve got four screenplays in various states of development.

‘There’s no question about it, as you get older, you get more marginalised.’

But the writers said they would not criticise current sitcoms and ‘there’s never been a better time to be a writer’ due to the number of companies and channels around.
